name: Krishna
subtitle: The Supreme Personality of Godhead - Eighth Avatar of Vishnu
description: Krishna (Sanskrit: 'the dark one' or 'all-attractive') is the eighth avatar of Vishnu and for many Hindus, the supreme manifestation of the divine. Unlike other avatars who descend for specific purposes, Krishna reveals the fullness of God's nature: as infant protector, mischievous child, enchanting cowherd, divine lover, wise counselor, and cosmic lord. His life spans the Bhagavata Purana and Mahabharata, culminating in the Bhagavad Gita, where he reveals himself to Arjuna as the Supreme Being and teaches the paths of action, knowledge, and devotion. Krishna's childhood in Vrindavan with the gopis (especially Radha) became the paradigm of bhakti (devotional love), while his role as Arjuna's charioteer at Kurukshetra shaped Hindu ethics. He is worshipped as Svayam Bhagavan (God himself) by Vaishnavas, particularly in the Gaudiya, Vallabha, and ISKCON traditions.

keyMyths.title: Birth and Escape from Kamsa
keyMyths.description: Krishna was born in Mathura's prison to Devaki and Vasudeva. King Kamsa, warned by prophecy that Devaki's eighth son would kill him, had killed her first seven children. When Krishna was born at midnight, the prison doors opened, guards fell asleep, and Vasudeva carried the infant across the flooding Yamuna River to Vrindavan, exchanging him for Yashoda's newborn daughter.

keyMyths.title: Childhood Miracles in Vrindavan
keyMyths.description: As a child, Krishna performed countless miracles: he killed the demoness Putana who tried to poison him with her breast milk; crawled between two trees to free cursed gandharvas; and defeated demons including Trinavarta, Bakasura, and Aghasuraâ€”all while appearing as an ordinary cowherd child.

keyMyths.title: Lifting Govardhan Hill
keyMyths.description: When the villagers prepared to worship Indra, king of the gods, Krishna persuaded them to worship Govardhan Hill instead. Enraged, Indra sent devastating rains for seven days. Krishna lifted the entire mountain on his little finger, sheltering the village beneath it. Indra, humbled, acknowledged Krishna's supremacy.

keyMyths.title: The Rasa Lila (Divine Dance)
keyMyths.description: On autumn nights, Krishna played his flute, calling the gopis (cowherd women) of Vrindavan to dance with him in the forest. He multiplied himself so each gopi believed she danced with Krishna alone. This Rasa Lila became the supreme symbol of the soul's loving union with God, the highest form of bhakti.

keyMyths.title: Slaying of Kamsa
keyMyths.description: Krishna and Balarama were invited to Mathura for a wrestling match. Krishna killed Kamsa's champion wrestlers and then slew the tyrant king himself, fulfilling the prophecy and freeing his parents from prison.

keyMyths.title: The Bhagavad Gita
keyMyths.description: At Kurukshetra, on the eve of the great war between Pandavas and Kauravas, Arjuna despaired at fighting his kinsmen. Krishna, his charioteer, delivered the Bhagavad Gita's 700 verses of spiritual teaching: the paths of action (karma yoga), knowledge (jnana yoga), and devotion (bhakti yoga). He revealed his cosmic form (Vishvarupa) and declared: 'Abandon all dharmas and surrender to me alone; I will deliver you from all sin.'

keyMyths.title: Departure from the World
keyMyths.description: After the Mahabharata war, the Yadava clan destroyed itself in drunken fighting, as cursed. Krishna, meditating in the forest, was struck in the heel by a hunter's arrow (mistaking him for a deer). He departed this world, returning to his eternal abode. This marked the beginning of the Kali Yuga, the present age of darkness.

comparativeNotes.greek: Like Apollo, Krishna is associated with music, beauty, and cattle; like Dionysus, with ecstatic devotion and divine dance
comparativeNotes.nearEastern: The infant hero saved from a murderous king echoes Moses and Jesus's nativity narratives
comparativeNotes.buddhist: Krishna bhakti influenced and was influenced by Pure Land Buddhism's devotional practices
comparativeNotes.universal: The divine child who defeats monsters and enchants through beauty appears cross-culturally

christianComparativeNotes.overview: Krishna has been central to Hindu-Christian dialogue since the 19th century. The parallels between Krishna and Christ are striking enough that scholars continue to debate historical connections, though most now attribute them to typological patterns rather than borrowing.
christianComparativeNotes.incarnation: Both Krishna and Christ are divine beings who take on full human natureâ€”Krishna as Vishnu's purna avatar, Christ as the eternal Logos made flesh. Both descend for the world's salvation.
christianComparativeNotes.miracleBirth: Both are born in miraculous circumstances: Krishna to imprisoned parents, transported to safety; Christ to a virgin in Bethlehem. Both face a king (Kamsa/Herod) who kills infants trying to destroy them.
christianComparativeNotes.childEscapeToSafety: Both infant saviors are hidden from murderous rulersâ€”Krishna in Vrindavan, Jesus in Egypt. The 'massacre of innocents' motif appears in both.
christianComparativeNotes.shepherdTheme: Both are associated with pastoral imagery: Krishna as Gopala (cowherd) among the cattle; Christ as the Good Shepherd (John 10). Both protect their 'flock.'
christianComparativeNotes.teacherOfDharma: Both deliver definitive spiritual teachings: Krishna's Bhagavad Gita on the paths to liberation; Christ's Sermon on the Mount on the Kingdom of God. Both reinterpret traditional religious law.
christianComparativeNotes.divineRevelation: Both reveal their cosmic nature to chosen disciples: Krishna's Vishvarupa (universal form) to Arjuna; Christ's Transfiguration to Peter, James, and John.
christianComparativeNotes.deathByPiercing: Both die from wounds to the body: Krishna's heel pierced by an arrow, Christ's side pierced by a lance. Both deaths mark transitions in cosmic time.
christianComparativeNotes.devotionalLove: Krishna bhakti and Christian mysticism share the language of divine love, bride-bridegroom imagery, and loving surrender. The Song of Songs and Gita Govinda use similar erotic-spiritual metaphors.
christianComparativeNotes.missionaryEncounter: 19th-century missionaries debated whether Krishna was a demon-distortion of Christ or whether Hindu devotion prepared hearts for the Gospel. Figures like Brahmabandhab Upadhyay attempted synthesis.
keyDistinctions: Krishna is one of many avatars; Christ is the unique incarnation of God
Krishna's death is accidental (hunter's mistake); Christ's death is purposeful atonement
Krishna teaches many paths (yoga); Christ declares 'I am the way' (John 14:6)
Krishna's lila (divine play) includes morally ambiguous acts; Christ is 'without sin' (Hebrews 4:15)
Krishna returns to his eternal abode; Christ promises to return to transform creation

sources: Bhagavata Purana (c. 9th-10th century CE): The primary source for Krishna's life, especially the Tenth Canto (Dashama Skandha).
Mahabharata (c. 4th century BCE - 4th century CE): Contains the Bhagavad Gita and Krishna's role in the great war.
Bhagavad Gita: 700-verse dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna, foundational Hindu scripture.
Vishnu Purana (c. 4th-5th century CE): Earlier account of Krishna's life.
Harivamsa (c. 1st-3rd century CE): Appendix to Mahabharata focusing on Krishna.
Gita Govinda by Jayadeva (12th century CE): Poetic celebration of Krishna and Radha's love.
modernScholarship: Edwin Bryant, Krishna: The Beautiful Legend of God (2003): Translation of Bhagavata Purana Book 10
John Stratton Hawley, Krishna the Butter Thief (1983): Study of childhood Krishna devotion
Graham Schweig, Dance of Divine Love: Rasa Lila (2005): Analysis of Krishna's sacred dance
